graphicslib3D

Interface ICamera

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    Camera

    public interface ICamera
    ICamera specifies the interface to be implemented by a "UVN" camera. It is the intent of this interface that camera implementations use a left-handed convention; that is, that the camera's N axis points in the camera View Direction. Applications using, e.g., OpenGL, need to account for the fact that the N axis in OpenGL is interpreted to be coming out the BACK of the camera (i.e., it points in the opposite of the view direction).
    Author:
    John Clevenger

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Point3D getLocation()
      Returns the location of the camera in world coordinate space.
      double[] getPerspectiveFrustumSettings()
      Returns an array containing the values defining the current camera view volume frustum settings.
      Vector3D getRightAxis()
      Returns the camera local-space "right axis" (sometimes called the camera's "X" or "U" axis).
      Vector3D getUpAxis()
      Returns the camera local-space "up axis" (sometimes called the camera's "Y" or "V" axis).
      Vector3D getViewDirection()
      Returns the camera local-space "view direction axis" (sometimes called the camera's "Z" or "N" axis).
      void moveForward(float amount)
      Moves the camera forward (along the direction of its view; that is, along the direction of its N axis).
      void moveUp(float amount)
      Moves the camera up/down (along the direction of its V axis).
      void pitch(float degrees)
      Applies a pitch of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its Right (U) axis by the specified amount in degrees.
      void roll(float degrees)
      Applies a roll of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its view direction (N) axis by the specified amount in degrees.
      void setAxes(Vector3D right, Vector3D up, Vector3D viewDir)
      A convenience method for setting all three camera axes at once.

      Sets the camera's position to the specified world location.

      Sets the parameters defining the camera perspective view volume (frustum).

      Sets the camera's "right" ("U" or "X") axis to the given Vector3D.

      Sets the camera's "up" ("Y" or "V") axis to the given Vector3D.

      Sets the camera's "view direction" ("Z" or "N") axis to the given Vector3D.

      Moves the camera left/right (along the direction of its U axis).
      void yaw(float degrees)
      Applies a yaw of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its Up (V) axis by the specified amount in degrees.

    • Method Detail

      • getRightAxis

        Vector3D getRightAxis()
        Returns the camera local-space "right axis" (sometimes called the camera's "X" or "U" axis).
        Returns:
        a Vector3D pointing in the direction of the camera's "right" axis.

      • getUpAxis

        Vector3D getUpAxis()
        Returns the camera local-space "up axis" (sometimes called the camera's "Y" or "V" axis).
        Returns:
        a Vector3D pointing in the direction of the camera's "up" axis.

      • getViewDirection

        Vector3D getViewDirection()
        Returns the camera local-space "view direction axis" (sometimes called the camera's "Z" or "N" axis).
        Returns:
        a Vector3D pointing in the direction of the camera's "view direction" axis.

      • getLocation

        Point3D getLocation()
        Returns the location of the camera in world coordinate space.
        Returns:
        a Point3D giving the camera's world location

      • setRightAxis

        void setRightAxis(Vector3D right)
        Sets the camera's "right" ("U" or "X") axis to the given Vector3D. Note that it is the responsibility of the client to insure that when camera axes are changed that they still form an orthogonal system (that is, that the camera's axes remain mutually perpendicular).
        Parameters:
        right - - the new camera "right" axis

      • setUpAxis

        void setUpAxis(Vector3D up)
        Sets the camera's "up" ("Y" or "V") axis to the given Vector3D. Note that it is the responsibility of the client to insure that when camera axes are changed that they still form an orthogonal system (that is, that the camera's axes remain mutually perpendicular).
        Parameters:
        up - - the new camera "up" axis

      • setViewDirection

        void setViewDirection(Vector3D dir)
        Sets the camera's "view direction" ("Z" or "N") axis to the given Vector3D. Note that it is the responsibility of the client to insure that when camera axes are changed that they still form an orthogonal system (that is, that the camera's axes remain mutually perpendicular).
        Parameters:
        dir - - the new camera "view direction" axis

      • setLocation

        void setLocation(Point3D loc)
        Sets the camera's position to the specified world location.
        Parameters:
        loc - - the new camera location

      • setAxes

        void setAxes(Vector3D right,
             Vector3D up,
             Vector3D viewDir)
        A convenience method for setting all three camera axes at once. Note that it is the responsibility of the client to insure that when camera axes are changed that they still form an orthogonal system (that is, that the camera's axes remain mutually perpendicular). Note also that this interface assumes that the N axis points in the view direction (unlike the OpenGL camera, where N comes out the BACK of the camera).
        Parameters:
        right - - the new camera "right" (U) axis
        up - - the new camera "up" (V) axis
        viewDir - - the new camera "view direction" (N) axis

      • pitch

        void pitch(float degrees)
        Applies a pitch of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its Right (U) axis by the specified amount in degrees.
        Parameters:
        degrees - - the amount of pitch to apply; a positive angle produces a counter-clockwise rotation about the camera's U axis.

      • yaw

        void yaw(float degrees)
        Applies a yaw of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its Up (V) axis by the specified amount in degrees.
        Parameters:
        degrees - - the amount of yaw to apply; a positive angle produces a counter-clockwise rotation about the camera's V axis.

      • roll

        void roll(float degrees)
        Applies a roll of the specified amount to the camera; that is, rotates the camera about its view direction (N) axis by the specified amount in degrees.
        Parameters:
        degrees - - the amount of roll to apply; a positive angle produces a counter-clockwise rotation about the camera's N axis.

      • moveForward

        void moveForward(float amount)
        Moves the camera forward (along the direction of its view; that is, along the direction of its N axis). The amount parameter controls how far to move; if amount is negative then the camera moves backward.

      • strafe

        void strafe(float amount)
        Moves the camera left/right (along the direction of its U axis). The amount parameter controls how far to move; if amount is negative then the camera moves left; otherwise it moves right.

      • moveUp

        void moveUp(float amount)
        Moves the camera up/down (along the direction of its V axis). The amount parameter controls how far to move; if amount is negative then the camera moves down; otherwise it moves up.

      • setPerspectiveFrustum

        void setPerspectiveFrustum(double fovY,
                           double aspect,
                           double near,
                           double far)
        Sets the parameters defining the camera perspective view volume (frustum). Note that it is up to clients which implement this interface to decide whether invocations of this method actually apply the specified view volume to the underlying graphics system, or instead simply save the specified values and rely on application code to obtain the current frustum settings and apply them to the underlying system independently.
        Parameters:
        fovY - - the vertical (Y) angle of the frustum, in degrees
        aspect - - the aspect ratio (width/height) of the view frustum
        near - - the distance from the camera to the near clipping plane; must be > 0
        far - - the distance from the camera to the far clipping plane; must be > near
        See Also:
        getPerspectiveFrustumSettings()

      • getPerspectiveFrustumSettings

        double[] getPerspectiveFrustumSettings()
        Returns an array containing the values defining the current camera view volume frustum settings. This method can be used by application code to obtain the current camera view volume settings in order to apply them to the underlying graphics system.
        Returns:
        - an array of doubles, where [0]=fovY, [1]=aspect ratio, [2]=near plane distance and [3]= far plane distance
